ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learned a lot more about history writing
I learned about 20th century Japanese history.

I gained a better understanding of the events that led to Japan's form of right-wing imperialism during WWII, both the historical background and the ideologies that they used to justify their actions. We covered a lot of ground in the course, but every topic was treated with a lot of nuance and there was a lot of emphasis on a mode of critical historical thinking. This was the best introduction to Japanese History I could've asked for. We also discussed various throughlines between pre and postwar Japan, ones that would definitely surprise you and help to cast light on the state of affairs in Japan and Asia today.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The content of the course is interesting and the lectures were very organized which facilitated student learning.
Great organization, great lecturer and well-led sections! The final exam format was a little confusing but felt fair

Great course, Professor Shepherd probably could use a little bit more repetitions lecturingat times she moved too fast or too slow, but overall she was very enthusiastic about teaching which is always very appreciated in a professor.

I thought the readings for this course were incredible: very well-curated and engaging. They were not overwhelming but I also feel like every week we were able to reach the crux of the topics of discussion through critically analyzing the readings. The lectures were also very well designed and paced. We covered a lot of ground but it never felt rushed or too shallow. The class was also the perfect size at around 20 students, so it felt like the perfect mix of a smaller, more engaging lecture where we could ask and answer questions freely, and delve more deeply into our own understandings of the topics in section.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes its a great overview class about Japanese history for non-history majors or history majors in other fields.
Yes! The content was really interesting and I felt that I learned a lot and improved in my writing.
Yes, but be aware that this course covers a lot of ground.

Absolutely. It was the best history and lecture course I've taken here at Yale. It doesn't feel too overwhelming in terms of workload but I think you get a lot out of the class. Especially for someone who hadn't really studied non-western history before, this was an excellent course that didn't assume too much prior knowledge but was also very intellectually stimulating as it introduced us to 20th century Japan.
